title: 107_hr4725
content: The Act is titled the "District of Columbia Tax Incentives Improvement Act of 2002" and it includes modifications to enterprise zone benefits available in the District of Columbia. The "District of Columbia Tax Incentives Improvement Act of 2002" designates the District of Columbia as an empowerment zone, treated similarly to other empowerment zones under the Internal Revenue Code. Amendments are made to section 1400 of the Code to reflect this designation. The "District of Columbia Tax Incentives Improvement Act of 2002" amends section 1400 of the Internal Revenue Code to apply the employment credit rule for the DC Zone, substituting '20' for '15' in the table. This change only applies to qualified zone employees in the DC Zone. The District of Columbia Tax Incentives Improvement Act of 2002 amends section 1400 of the Internal Revenue Code by changing the employment credit rule for the DC Zone. This includes amending subsections and paragraphs related to capital gains exclusion for assets held more than 2 years. The District of Columbia Tax Incentives Improvement Act of 2002 amends section 1400 of the Internal Revenue Code by changing the employment credit rule for the DC Zone to a 2-year term. Modifications to the definition of DC Zone Business are also made, specifying criteria for businesses in the District of Columbia. The District of Columbia Tax Incentives Improvement Act of 2002 amends the employment credit rule for DC Zone businesses. The special rule for businesses holding intangibles is modified, requiring a certain percentage of employees and wages to be residents of the District of Columbia. The effective date of these amendments is retroactive to the Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997. The District of Columbia Tax Incentives Improvement Act of 2002 extends the enterprise zone treatment until December 31, 2009. It also extends the effective period for economic development bonds and zero percent capital gains rate until January 1, 2010 and 2014 respectively. Additionally, the first-time homebuyer credit for District of Columbia is made permanent with other modifications. The first-time homebuyer credit for District of Columbia is made permanent by amending the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Purchases in connection with divorce are also addressed, allowing individuals to be treated as first-time homebuyers under certain circumstances. The first-time homebuyer credit for District of Columbia is made permanent by amending the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The credit can be claimed if the residence was the principal residence of the individual at the time of sale or for a period ending not more than a reasonable period before the sale. Regulations will be prescribed to prevent abuse of this provision. The amendment applies to purchases after the enactment date. The credit is limited based on the amount of tax owed. The first-time homebuyer credit for District of Columbia is made permanent by amending the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The credit is limited based on the amount of tax owed and any excess can be carried over to the succeeding taxable year. Amendments are made to ensure compliance and prevent abuse of the provision. The amendment made by paragraph (1) applies to taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. EXPANSION OF TAX-EXEMPT ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT BONDS. Amends Section 1400A of the Internal Revenue Code to address tax-exempt economic development bonds. In the District of Columbia Enterprise Zone, certain provisions regarding bonds are exempted, employee residency requirement is disregarded, and bonds are treated as not private activity bonds. This applies to bonds issued between January 1, 1998, and December 31, 2009, with amendments effective for bonds issued after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 6. Bonds issued by the District of Columbia are exempt from state and local taxes, effective for taxable years after December 31, 2001. SEC. 7. Zero percent withholding rate on payments for DC zone insurance policies. SEC. 1400D. Zero percent withholding rate on payments for DC zone insurance policies. The tax and withholding rates for payments made by an exempt insurance company with respect to a DC Zone insurance policy are zero. An exempt insurance company is defined as a company subject to tax under subchapter L and is a DC Zone business. A DC Zone insurance policy refers to an insurance or annuity contract issued by an exempt insurance company in connection with property in the DC Zone. An exempt insurance company is not required to report amounts paid under a DC Zone insurance policy to a non-US person if the contract is regulated by the Department of Insurance and Securities Regulation of the District of Columbia and no policyholder, insured, annuitant, or beneficiary is a US person. The text chunk discusses exemptions for reporting amounts paid under a DC Zone insurance policy to a non-US person. It also mentions a clerical amendment to the table of sections for a specific subchapter. The text chunk introduces a zero percent withholding rate on payments for DC Zone insurance policies. The effective date for these amendments is after the enactment of the Act.
